newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thai PM seeks to reassure foreign creditors.
newsitem.headline: Thai PM seeks to reassure foreign creditors.

text.p: Thai Prime Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh assured anxious foreign creditors Sunday that they would be fairly treated if Thai private companies defaulted amid the country's economic turmoil.
After a meeting with bankers from 25 foreign financial institutions, Chavalit said foreign creditors had expressed deep concern over their exposure to the troubled Thai private sector.
The meeting was organised by the foreign banks' association, which sought assurances of fair and equitable treatment as economic problems intensified.
"They are worried. So I assured them that they will be treated fairly. I also told them what the government plans to do to solve the problem," he said.
According to participants in the meeting, Chavalit told them of Thailand's plan to accept an International Monetary Fund (IMF) economic rescue package but gave no details.
He also asked them to cooperate by extending credit lines and rolling over loans to Thai companies, they said.
Thailand is facing a severe economic crisis after a decade of high growth.
The financial sector has been hard hit by a liquidity crunch and rising non-performing loans due to over-exposure to non-productive industry, especially the property sector.
The country is now seeking help from the IMF to put it back on track. Details of the rescue package are expected to be announced next week.
